ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had a guest speaker/Q and A during one seminar.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed an ability to more closely read, understand, explain, and discuss poetry. I also learned to improve my essay writing and analysis of poetry.

This class strengthened my ability to critically read and respond to poetry, from both an academic and personal standpoint. I also learned so much about my own spiritualityand how to articulate and question itby hearing from Professor Wiman and my classmates and reading poets perspectives on faith.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was an amazing course. I have never had better discussions with my classmates. Despite the Zoom format, discussions flowed well and included everyone. None of us wanted the class to end.

I can honestly cannot think of any weaknesses. The weekly assignments felt like the perfect amount - each time reading a series of poems grouped around a common theme and writing in a journal to reflect on them. Class time was a great balance of activities - break out groups, full discussion, reciting or listening to poems, and doing small writing activities. I had been nervous about the emphasis on recitation, but after the exercises, you are left with poems of your choice to carry with you beyond class.

The course reader and class discussions are incredible but the quality of the discussion, like in all seminars, depends on the preparedness of all the other students. In this course, where the poetry demands a certain degree of vulnerability on the part of the students, everyone needs to be especially respectful, attentive, and invested in the course for it to go smoothly. This semester it definitely did but I can imagine with a different cohort it could be challenging.

This course was my favorite of the semester, and I looked forward to the seminar every single week. The class felt for me as much like a spiritual discussion group as a poetry analysis course, and I cant overstate how much I valued the sense of community I felt with Professor Wiman and my classmates. I really appreciated the journaling exercise that accompanied the reading homework each week: the prompts were thought-provoking but never constricting. My journal felt very personal, especially because we didnt share them every week, and it also always made me feel prepared to raise specific comments in seminar about poems or ideas that struck me. Finally, I loved that we were encouraged to take liberties with the final assignment and short presentations throughout the course: I felt that I always had the space to follow my own passions, and I learned so much from my classmates because they had the space to do the same. I wouldnt change a thing about this course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was quite small, which made it easier to interact on Zoom. The professor frequently used breakout rooms for even smaller discussions, which also helped.

The ability to have poets cone as guest speakers to class was a fun addition that might not occur in the normal class. Prof. Wiman also skillfully used the breakout rooms to conduct small group discussions.
The fact that I felt close to every person in my Zoom seminar without ever actually meeting them speaks volumes. I felt that the course was constructed as well as it possibly could be during COVID!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. Anyone interested in exploring faith and learning about poetry, from a skeptic to a devout practitioner, and from someone who has never read a poem to a practiced poet, could benefit from this course.

Absolutely - this is one of the best classes Ive taken at Yale (and if you dont get in the first time, try again next year. Its so worth it). The reading is never too heavy each week, but the content provides so much to dive into personally and through class discussion, not just regarding questions of faith, but also joy, suffering, conceptions of home etc. Also, its not every day that you get to take a class with the former editor of Poetry magazine. Prof. Wiman is so insightful, down to earth, and has published a lot of the poems that you read in class!
Absolutely, this class is worth it for Prof. Wimans instruction alone.

Absolutely!! Whether or not youve ever taken a poetry class before, and whether or not youve ever thought of yourself as a person of faithI barely had before taking the courseyou will absolutely gain something from the course. I feel so grateful to have spent time in an environment that was both incredibly intellectually stimulating and personally fulfilling. I learned so much about poetry, faith, and my own relationship to both.
